thread.title: FINAL: FCS school Portland State runs over North Texas 66-7; full coverage here
thread.title_full: FINAL: FCS school Portland State runs over North Texas 66-7; full coverage here | Dallas Morning News

author: Brett Vito
title: FINAL: FCS school Portland State runs over North Texas 66-7; full coverage here
text:
Five thoughts: Changes seem imminent after Mean Green's 66-7 loss to FCS Portland State
North Texas' Dan McCarney fired following Mean Green's 66-7 loss to FCS school
DENTON -- By the time Dan McCarney walked off the turf at Apogee Stadium for the last time as North Texas' head coach on Saturday night, the stands were nearly empty.
UNT's students and most of its alumni had cleared out by then at the end of a devastating 66-7 loss on a night of change for the Mean Green's program. McCarney was fired following a setback that UNT athletic director Rick Villarreal said was an indication of how far the program had fallen since a win over UNLV in the 2013 Heart of Dallas Bowl.
The Mean Green's loss to Portland State was its sixth straight dating to last season. It was also also UNT's first loss to a team competing on the Football Championship Subdivision since the school resumed playing on the Football Bowl Subdivision level in 1995.
UNT was 8-0 against FCS teams since that season, a streak the Mean Green never came close to extending against Portland State.
"When you come up short on the scoreboard and are off to the start we are this season, it's disheartening and disappointing because I see how hard everyone works," McCarney said.
The Vikings came into the night ranked 25th on the FCS level and upset Washington State earlier in the year.
There was never much of a question that Portland State would make UNT its second FBS victim of the year.
The Mean Green were never really competitive against the Vikings and fell to 0-5 for the first time since 2008.
The Vikings (4-1) certainly looked the part while dismantling the Mean Green. Portland State rolled up a whopping 670 total yards and held UNT scoreless until the Mean Green scored a meaningless touchdown on a pass from backup quarterback DaMarcus Smith to wide receiver Carlos Harris with 1:02 left.
Alex Kuresa threw for 269 yards and three touchdowns on just 19 attempts, while David Jones rushed for 134 yards and two touchdowns on nine carries. Andrew McNulty threw for 57 yards and Carlos Harris added 57 receiving yards for the Mean Green.
